channel.title: MHC1
channel.generator: Webpage HTML Export plugin for Obsidian
channel.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: 2mi Results JAN2025
item.description:
Results Google Sheet (ask me for access)

UPDATE: 4 more individuals did the assessment on 03JAN. The goal is to create A/B/C training groups. For missing members I made a best guess for which group they fit into.
14 participants, still missing a few crewmembers
I believe the course is 10 seconds slower than on a track (elevation + hard turn around).

Observations
Group's average time was ~17 minutes
All but one person overestimated their performance
Average "best guess" overestimated performance by 10%
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: 2mi Course
item.description:
The 2 mile time trial is an Aerobic Fitness assessment. Participants should run the course at max effort. The goal of facilitators is to accurately record times.


Start / Finish
37.350556, -121.909611
https://maps.app.goo.gl/w3Mhe8jBNwVWkPZc8
Turn Around Point
37.363177, -121.918540
https://maps.app.goo.gl/x1tttuhTQDGpJkVA9
Hazards
Missing the turn around
If you reach Skyport Dr overpass (overpass #2), you've gone too far.
Unpaved sections
Uneven dirt, rocks, mud, puddles
Members of public, homeless



Time keeper at Start / Finish
Needs a clipboard / pen / blank results sheet(ask me for file permission).
Stopwatch
Turn around person or clearly mark Turn Around (flagging tape + signage)


Jog from station to Start / Finish
Explain this an out & back, how to identify the turn around point
5 minutes to prepare, turn around person leaves to get in position
Mass start, begin timer
Crewmembers run to turn around point and return
Time keeper records times as crewmembers finish
Return to station
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: Ability Run
item.description:
Goal is to have everyone run for 40 minutes. Groups serve to tailor the pace to crew member's ability.
Target intensity is relatively low (Zone 2, conversational pace, etc.). Emphasis on duration over intensity to get the best aerobic stimulus.
Procedure

Divide crews into A / B / C groups based on ability
Instruct groups to run out for 20 minutes along creek and turn back
Inform groups of approximate goal pace / distance for 40 minutes
Return at the same pace (in 20 minutes)
Do not drop anyone from your group, stick together!
Record each group's actual time / distance
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: All In One
item.description:
3 dynamics lifts targeting push / pull / legs respectively. Based off the "Operator" template from Tactical Barbell 1. (see Recommended Reading)

Back Squat (alternative: Hex Bar Dead Lift)
Weight: 75% of one rep max
3 sets x 5-8 reps
Bench Press
Weight: 75% of one rep max
3 sets x 5-8 reps
Pull Up
Reps: 75% of max consecutive reps
3 sets
** Do 5 reps of negatives if you cannot do more than 3 consecutive pull ups
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: Leg Day
item.description:
Set up

Station 1 next to kettle bells for goblet squat
Station 2 setup rack nearest mirror for back squat
Station 3 near the door stage some dumb bells for lunges (weight is optional)
Procedure

Demo the back squat for good form
Split the crew into A / B / C groups based on ability
Emphasize rest between sets while someone in the group is exercising. Use the time efficiently.
Rotate every ~12 minutes
Movements
Groups will rotate through each station such that each group is doing a different movement

5x 8-10 Goblet squat (with kettle / dumbbells). Emphasize depth and focus
4x 6-10 reps at 80% of 1 rep max
5x 10 reps each leg, added weight is optional
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: Pull Day
item.description:
Procedure

Demo the lat pull down (straight arms) and bent row (good posture)
Split crew into A / B / C groups based on ability
Emphasize rest between sets while someone in the group is exercising. Use the time efficiently.
Rotate every ~12 minutes
Movements
All groups will do the same movement at separate stations. If space is limited, it's possible to have 1 station / movement and rotate.

4x 5-8 Bicep Curls (dumbbells)
4x 5-8 Bent Row (barbell)
4x 5-8 Lat Pull Down (straight arms, pulley machine)
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: Push Day
item.description:
Warm Ups

5 min around the world
3x5-8 unilateral dumbbell press
Procedure

Demo the bench press for good form.
Split crew into A / B / C groups based on ability
Emphasize rest between sets while someone in the group is exercising. Use the time efficiently.
Rotate every ~12 minutes
Movements
All groups will do the same movement at separate stations. If space is limited, it's possible to have 1 station / movement and rotate.

4x 8-12 Tricep Extensions
4x 4-8 Incline Dumbbell Press
4x 6-8 Bench Press @ 75% of one rep max
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: EMOM #1
item.description:
emom-music

3 groups / 3 "lanes" with an exercise to be completed Every Minute On The Minute.
Layout

Basketball court divided into 3 lanes long ways
Stage 2x hex bars + 1x barbell loaded with plates for dead lift
Stage 3x pairs of heavy dumbbells (+/- 50 lbs each) for farmers carry
Workout
Start EMOM music (see above). For each minute

Lane 1: 3 reps dead lift
Lane 2: Fireman's carry in pairs OR farmers carry with dumbbells
Lane 3: 10x burpees
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: EMOM #2
item.description:
emom-music


EMOM Mix 86, 30 min
EMOM Mix 54, 30 min
2 groups / 2 "lanes" with an exercise to be completed Every Minute On The Minute.
Layout

Basketball court divided into 2 lanes long ways
Stage the armory pull up bars
Each lane will have a designated activity that needs to be completed within a minute
Divide the crew by 2 and put each group on a lane
Workout
"Court Run" means run out an back the length of the b-ball court

Lane 1: Court Run + 4 Pull Ups
if you can't do pull ups, stage dumbells for dumbbell rows instead
Lane 2: Court Run + 10 Push Ups
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: EMOM Music
item.description:
EMOM Mix 86, 30 min
EMOM Mix 54, 30 min
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: Partial Murph
item.description:
0.5 mile run
50 pull ups or rows
150 push ups
200 squats
0.5 mile

item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: Crew PT
item.description:
PT Log
MHC1 Physical Training Proposal


2mi Course
2mi Results JAN2025


TODO: 1 Rep Max Procedure
TODO: 1 Rep Max Results


Tactical Barbell collection of books by K. Black
Disclaimer: PDFs are for educational purposes. Buy the books if you like them.
WHERE DO I START? forum post
TB I: Strength PDF
Most relevant to me because I want to get stronger
TB II: Conditioning PDF
Confusingly this is not a sequel to TB I, it's a stand alone book.
Have yet to read it as of JAN2025
TB Green Protocol PDF, endurance specialty book
Most relevant to Wildland Firefighting in general
Run For Your Life, Mark Cucuzzella, M.D.
Available on Hoopla free with your public library card
Author is a doctor, researcher, marathoner, ex Air Force
Running technique, energy system physiology, training methods

Attributes or fitness domains are things like maximal-strength, speed, strength-endurance or aerobic capacity. Tools are things like bench press, sandbags, kettle bells, hills, and your body weight. For the operational athlete, training is about improving the attribute, not about getting better at using the tool.
There’s block periodization wherein you focus on mostly one fitness domain at a time before moving on to the next. For example, block 1 would be several weeks focused on aerobic base building, block two might be maximal-strength and work capacity, and block 3 could be sport specific drills.
Periodization can also refer to how you manipulate frequency/volume and
progression within the context of strength training. [eg Progressive Overload]
Periodization gives you a plan. Before you set foot in the gym, you’ll know what exercises to perform, number of sets, number of reps and load.
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: MHC1 Physical Training Proposal
item.description:
SPC Shoemaker in collaboration with SPC Hammack
v20241231
In this plan I present an actionable guide to PT programming for the crew that aligns with well known principals of physical training to make us stronger, faster, and more durable. At minimum we should run 3 workouts per week that respectively target Max Strength, Aerobic Fitness, and Work Capacity. For Strength & Aerobic Fitness the crew should be divided into training groups based on measured ability for that particular domain.


The minimum allotted time for crew PT is 3h / week per Lt. Col. Riley.
The pairing of training stimulus followed by sufficient recovery yields physical improvement.
Progressive Overload training is how to developing Maximum Strength efficiently.
Endurance training at Aerobic Threshold effort is optimal for developing Aerobic Fitness.
Max Strength and Aerobic Fitness are the foundation of exceptional Work Capacity.[1]
All workouts must explicitly target one of the following domains of fitness:
Maximum Strength
Aerobic Fitness
Work Capacity
While training will sometimes be uncomfortable to achieve a sufficient stimulus, no single workout should break off a crew member. When we PT in the morning we must keep fire ready for the day. Excessive fatigue, vomiting, and pushing through acute pain are to be avoided. Such max efforts must be reserved for infrequent tests (Type Out), competitions (Stand Down), or an exceptional situation in the field where an absolute max effort is justified by the danger of the situation.


Progressive Overload: In strength training, this is the principal of adding more resistance over time in order to stimulate continued adaption and build strength efficiently.
Aerobic Fitness: The body's ability to effectively supply oxygen to muscles during sustained exercise such as hiking, cutting line, running at a steady pace, etc. Also responsible for resetting the anaerobic energy system after a short explosive effort.
Anaerobic Fitness: The body's ability to deliver short bursts of energy in the absence of oxygen. Examples include sprinting, HIIT, or moving heavy objects explosively.
Aerobic Threshold: A sustained effort just above the "optimal endurance training zone" and below an anaerobic effort.[2] A rule of thumb is to run at the limit of nasal breathing. This idea is similar to "Zone 2" or Long Steady State training.

Work capacity: "[T]he ability to recover quickly and use multiple muscle groups requiring your cardiovascular, musculoskeletal and central nervous system to work together efficiently".[3] This is critical for Wildland Firefighters who must perform dynamic physical tasks for prolonged periods.
Stimulus-Fatigue-Recovery-Adaptation (SFRA) Theory: The key idea is that fatigue induced by a training stimulus decreases apparent performance in the short term. Only with adequate rest is an increase in physical ability (Supercompensation) achieved.[4] Adaptation does not require total rest, however. You can target different stimulus day to day. One total rest day / week is advisable.


Given that we are allotted 3h / week minimum for crew PT, it makes sense to run a workout on Monday / Wednesday / Friday. The three workouts are purposefully very different to provide specific stimulus for Strength, Aerobic Fitness and Work capacity respectively:
Monday: Max Strength Specific lifting sessions will be designed by SPC Hammack and follow a cycle targeting Push, Pull, or Leg movements each week. Workouts will consist of 3 movements for 3-5 sets of 5-12 reps to optimize for Max Strength. Sufficient rest between sets to reset the body and maintain form is critical. For heavy dynamic movements, weight is assigned as a percentage of estimated 1 Repetition Maximum and should gradually increase overtime (Progressive Overload).
Wednesday: Aerobic Fitness Primarily organized by SPC Shoemaker, and typically a run at Aerobic Threshold effort. This is a high tempo, yet sustainable pace. Runs beyond 30 minutes are ideal stimulus and should be executed with near even splits. Overtime we expect to see more speed / distance at the same intensity (Aerobic Adaptation). Alternatively we can do a hike, ERG row, stationary bike, or continuous basketball day.
Friday: Work Capacity This is where we combine Max Strength & Aerobic Fitness for an up-tempo workout that bleeds into Anaerobic effort. This can be circuit training, HIIT, Every Minute on the Minute, or an Indian Run. It is the least structured workout and is meant to be a group challenge that simulates the dynamic work we must do on the fire line.
The most fit members of the crew can easily incorporate the M/W/F workouts into their programming. For the crew member that does no PT beyond what is prescribed, we expect to still see improvement via "beginner gains". SPC Hammack's Push / Pull / Leg specific workouts will allow less experienced lifters to learn new lifts do their own strength sessions. Likewise runs prescribed at Aerobic Threshold pace will give lesser runners a reprieve from crew runs that are too fast, while still giving them ideal stimulus to improve.

When organizing a PT session, it is simplest to assign the same workout to everyone. Given the variance in ability among the crew, this strategy violates Principal #6: All workouts must explicitly target either Strength, Aerobic Fitness, or Work Capacity. Why is this?
Let's say the crew is assigned a 4 mile run at 9'30" / mi pace. For the most capable runner on the crew, this pace is well below their Aerobic Threshold pace of 7'45" / mi. For the worst runner they will quickly exceed their aerobic limit and fall off the pace, despite giving their max effort. Both are receiving a sub-optimal stimulus in opposite directions. And for the crew member who went anaerobic, the stimulus is unproductive: The "toxic, acidic environment in the muscles [from high-intensity workouts] inhibit the aerobic development we seek."[5]
You can imagine a similar scenario for a strength workout with free weights: The strongest crew member can easily squat a barbell loaded with 250 lbs whereas an inexperienced lifter will risk injury by handling such weight. It's unproductive.
The worst possible result of overwhelming stimulus is over training or injury. This happens when the Stimulus-Fatigue (of SFRA Theory) compounds in the absence of Recovery-Adaption such that P (Performance) degrades in the long term. We can avoid this.

A straight forward solution to the above problems is to create workout-specific "teams" based on measured ability.
Let's reframe the 4 mile crew run from above: We want the crew to run approximately 40 minutes at a pace that is close to their Aerobic Threshold. Let's split thew crew into Alpha, Bravo & Charlie groups. Alpha will run at 8' / mi for 5 miles. Bravo will run at 9'30" / mi for 4 miles. Charlie will run at 11' / mi for 3.5 miles. The variance in distance / pace of each group allows us to roughly normalize the 40 minutes of aerobic training stimulus for everyone.
We can determine the running teams by collecting 2 mi time trial results. We can then calculate and assign Aerobic Threshold paces and test if they are appropriate with feedback and GPS tracking.
Similarly for strength sessions, we can assign A/B/C groups based on measured 1 Rep Max for dynamic lifts. Taking a percentage of that result allows us to determine the team's training weight for a given movement. We can employ Progressive Overload by increasing that percentage over time.
To ensure the training groups are split correctly and that assigned workouts are effective, we will need to constantly receive feedback and adjust. Maybe the training weight was too easy for an individual, and they should move up a group. Maybe the group as a whole has improved, and they are ready for a modest increase in weight. Within a group stronger individuals can bump up the reps so long as they are capable of completing all the assigned sets.
While the Strength and Aerobic Fitness sessions should be split into teams, I envision the Work Capacity workouts to be done together as a crew, doubling as a teamwork and morale building exercise.

For much of the crew the M/W/F programming is not enough to continue progressing. The frequency of stimulus isn't there so additional runs and lifts throughout the week would flesh out the training. To help people focus their efforts we can ask what their individual fitness goals are and check in with them periodically. Example goals could be to bench press one's body weight for 1 rep, run the 2 mile in 14 minutes, or do 1 rep of 1.5x bodyweight for the Back Squat, etc..
By hitting the three major workouts weekly, tailoring stimulus via workout teams, and promoting a culture of regular and purposeful training, we can become a more competitive, durable, and capable crew.


Start the M/W/F workout cycle.
Create groups and plan workouts with available info.
Execute the 1 Rep Max Day & 2 Mile Test Day to calculate training figures.
Continuously monitor and adjust programming based on individual and team progress / feedback.
Collect personal fitness goals. Periodically monitor progress.
Repeat the 1 Rep Max Day and 2 Mile Test Day every 3 months.
1 Rep Max Day

Goal: Test individuals' 1 Rep Max as input for A/B/C training teams and computed training weight.
Training weight calculation:
Take the 1 rep and multiply it by some percentage in the range of 50-80%.
For example a 1 Rep Max of 220lbs at 70% yields a training weight of ~150lbs.
The percentage will increase over time as the team adapts (Progressive Overload).
Procedure
Warm up specific to the movement
Coaching on the movement
Break out into groups to test 1 Rep Max for:
Bench Press
Back Squat
(Hex Bar) Dead Lift
2 Mile Test Day

Goal: Measure relative running ability as input for A/B/C training teams and computed Aerobic Threshold training pace.
Aerobic Threshold training pace calculation:
Plug the 2 mile time into the Luke Humphrey Running Pace Calculator[6] and record the faster limit of the "Moderate" pace output.
For example a 14 minute 2 mile will yield a "Moderate" pace output of 9'10" / mi pace for the faster limit.
Procedure
1 mile warm up and dynamic stretches
Set up timers and course (ideally at a track)
Run 2 mi at max effort
Record times
Cool down

Max Strength: Push Day

Warm up
Emphasize rest between reps for quality sets, 2-3 minutes minimum
Break out into A/B/C teams & cycle through the following exercises:
4x 6-8 Barbell Bench Press
5x 8-12 Tricep push downs
4x 6-8 seated shoulder press
Aerobic Fitness: ~40 minute Aerobic Threshold Run

Dynamic warm up
Emphasize even pacing, stick with your team
Break out into teams:
Alpha: Run at 8' / mi for 5 miles
Bravo: Run at 9'30" / mi for 4 miles
Charlie: Run at 11'00 / mi for 3.5 miles
Group stretch
Work Capacity: Every Minute On the Minute (EMOM)

Warm up
EMOM for 20 minutes. For each minute do:
Basketball court out and back sprint
Alternate between push & pull
Push: 10x Push Up
Pull: 3x Pull Up or 5x Barbell Row
Group stretch








"Work Capacity Test" Brochure, United States Forest Service https://www.fs.usda.gov/sites/default/files/2023-03/Work-Capacity-Test-brochure.pdf↩︎
Run For Your Life: How to Run, Walk, and Move Without Pain or Injury, Mark Cucuzzella, Chapter 7↩︎
"What Is Your Work Capacity?", Stew Smith, Military.com, https://www.military.com/military-fitness/general-fitness/what-is-your-work-capacity↩︎
"The Science and Practice of Periodization: A Brief Review", Anthony Turner, London Sport Institute, Middlesex University, http://instituteofmotion.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/The_Science_and_Practice_of_Periodization.pdf↩︎
Run For Your Life: How to Run, Walk, and Move Without Pain or Injury, Mark Cucuzzella, Chapter 7↩︎
Luke Humphrey Running Pace Calculator, https://lukehumphreyrunning.com/hmmcalculator/race_equivalency_calculator.php↩︎
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: PT Log
item.description:
At Alviso Slough Marina County Park
Combined crews alpha & bravo. First 10 minutes was all together, then let it rip.

20 minute group stretch before wheels rolling
Cut at Santa Clara County Police Firearm Training Range
AM - Cutting upslope, grass at the bottom, then brush
PM - Side hill cut, alpha scraped, bravo digs trench

At Bear Creek Open Space Preserve
Roughly 3h hike / 8 miles / 1600ft of vertical
With full web gear + banjos
Strava Recording


30 minute flow. Led by PFC Mathews.

40 minutes

Time constrained to <30 minutes.
Instructions were to run 15 minutes out at assigned pace of A/B/C group, then optionally let it rip on the way back if you choose. What actually happened is the pace got pushed on the way out in every group. Most blew up on the way back. Not ideal. Asking for a change in pace, not for people to race (there is time and place for max efforts)

Many stations (too many stations.) Crews alternated running 3 laps around gym / two laps up / down the armory stairs after completing one cycle.

Led by SPC Hammack

EMOM: literally every piece of gym equipment we had, we used as a station (12+ stations). Instructions were to do as many reps as you can while maintaining form.
1h Hike at Sanborn, full climb up switchbacks and descent on the road

Per NCOIC

Per NCOIC

Went smoothly. I assembled everyone in the gym first. Assigned groups and described the parameters

This is not a race
Keep your group together. Don't be a hero and blow up your group in the first mile.
Turn around at 20 minutes. Pace yourselves such that you can return in 20 minutes.
40 min run results:
A: 4.5mi / 8:50 pace
B: 4.2mi / 9:30 pace
C: 3.4 mi / 11:25
I am happy with these paces. I sent out group A, then B, then C, which means groups would pass each other towards the end. This created a bit of a competitive climate which I think increased the paces slightly which is fine. If people want to compete, they will get their chance during the next 2 mile time trial.

Assigned by SPC Hammack

0.5 mile run
50 Pull ups or Rows
150 push ups
200 air squats
0.5 mile run


Hike: 45lbs, 3 miles, sub 45 minutes is the standard. No running!
Hand release push ups: 20 is the standard
Plank: 1'30" is the standard
Everyone passed!

Easy day, leading into pack hike for tomorrow

20 minute hike, steep terrain @ Oakland Project

Per NCOIC

20 minutes. Learned that 15 burpees / minute is too much. Bumped it down to 10x burpees.

Went smoothly, efficiently executed by the crew, rotating stations every ~12 minutes

1h basketball. Super Bowl LIX

This EMOM didn't work very well and won't be repeated
Lane 1: Buddy Carry
Lane 1: Half Court Lunges
Lane 2: Deadlift

1 set of 6 reps
3 options for weight:
Low: Barbell with two 25 plates
Med: Trap bar with 25, 10 on each side
High: Trap bar with 45, 10 on each side
Lane 3: Burpees

1 set of 15 reps
EMOM for 20 minutes, then free PT
For the lanes, set up equipment in columns. Things get confusing with 3 groups that have to rotate. Added EMOM music links to the EMOM pages. If we do lunges, they should be half court and run back. For simplicity maybe, everyone runs a court lap. For Lunges Lane, then do half court lunge and return.

Free PT for 1h per NCOIC

Lead by Hammack. Groups stuck together.
Group B ran 3.9 mi, 10:20 pace, 40 minutes

Small crew as most people are in LA. 15 minutes out and back. Pace was too hot and some people got dropped which I want to avoid in the future.
3.2 mi, 30 minutes, 9:30 pace

Aerobic Fitness stimulus
40 minutes of knock out. Easy day, everyone can participate, gets people running around.

Max Strength stimulus
Incline Dumbell press
4X 5-8 reps
2:30-3:00 min rest between sets
Tricep extensions
4X 8- 12 reps
2:00-3:00 min rest between sets
Barbell bench press
(Multiply 1rep max by .75 to find your working weight)
4X 5-8 reps
2:30-3:00 minute rest between sets
Groups start at there station and will rotate
Clockwise every 12 - 13 minutes

Better coordination with Bravo concerning free weight usage.

Work Capacity stimulus

15 cycles of
bb court run
alternating 5x hanging leg lift / 10x kb swing
materials
2x pull up bar
30-40lb kb & dumbells
(speaker)
Morning was time constrained. EMOM set up / break down is quick. Hammack’s EMOM music track is helpful. Crew enjoys the workout, high tempo but attainable for everyone.

Max Strength assessment
Hammack's self assessment:


First formation dismissal: gave time to prep gym
Technique instruction and how to safely fail a lift: Gave people confidence to try their best while avoiding injury
Non-formal "coaching" approach: Allowed Hammack to engage with crew in an approachable, encouraging way. Environment is non judgemental and safe for everyone.
Shoemaker acting as scribe: Allowed Hammack to give people attention as needed.

• Elaborate on the the importance of rest between warm ups / sets / 1 rep max attempts

Better crowd control: Some time spent in "bro session" mode, Bravo entered the gym and side tracked Alpha.
A more in depth class on technique prior to the session: Would cut down the time to complete the assessment

Aerobic Fitness assessment
2mi-results
I estimate the course is 10 sec slower than a track (slope, hard turn around). Placed pink flagging at turn around.
Before the assessment I asked people their “best guess” for a 2 mile time for two reasons:

Hammack thought self-reported times would overestimate performance. This was largely correct - average guess was 10% faster than recorded time.
My hope was that by stating a goal time, people would take the assessment more seriously and try to hit that time.
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: Clearing A Room
item.description:
25FEB2025
5 key steps

Get thru the door. Standing in the doorway makes you an easy target
Run your wall. First man gets to choose which direction he goes upon entering and must run the entire wall. 2nd man runs the opposite wall.
Clear your corner. After running your wall, make sure the corner is clear.
Scan your section. With the wall / corner cleared, scan for enemies. Do not shoot your teammates
Check / clear. Ensure threats have been neutralized and the space is considered "clear"
OPORD (operation order) determines your rules of engagement. Subject to change.
Use Noise Discipline to maintain the element of surprise before you enter the room
Stacking is the idea that the team is lined up closely and ready to move together as each man threads through the doorway,
1st man gets to choose which wall he wants to follow. The remaining stack will alternate directions accordingly.
Button hook means to sweep 180 degrees as you pass through the doorway. ⮑
2nd man in the stack is the considered the most dangerous position. The delayed reaction of a surprised enemy is likely to allow the 1st man to pass through but hit the 2nd man. 2nd man is typically the team leader.
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: Drill and Ceremony Basic Movements
item.description:
Fall in / out
Right / left / about face
Forward march
Mark time march
Halt
File from the left forward
SLs turn head to the right and say in unison
SL1: "Forward!"
SL2+: "Stand fast"
March
SL2 waits for end of rank 1, and issues the command: Forward march
SL3, etc
Present / order arms
Column left / right march
"march" is said on the same foot as the direction of the command
For example for "column left" say "march" on their left step, so that the can execute the left pivot on the next step with their right foot
Cover / recover
Dress right dress ... Ready front
Attention / parade rest / at ease / rest / fall out
right / left flank
unlike column left / right where SLs pivot first, the "flank" command has everyone pivot at the same time
rear march
similar to column right where the pivot will actually happen on the left foot
say "march" on the right step so that everyone can anticipate the pivot on their left step and turn around
Drill sergeant issues commands at the position of attention. For right face, forward march, the step and turn at the same time to immediately step in the same direction of the platoon.
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: Radio Clone Instructions
item.description:
18JAN2025

Determine if there is a new clone
Collect your radios and find the Radio Clone desk (homies with the laptops)
Before handing over your radios turn them ON & remove lapel mics
Ask which zones have new channels and tell your radio users
For example at Palisades they loaded Zones 51 & 52 with channels. Channels from a cloned zone should match your assigned channels in the IAP (tactical, command, etc).
Q1: What actually is a clone?
A1: As the radio user I can only edit Zones 1-9 by pulling channels from Zone 10 and above. Higher zones are apparently fixed and uneditable. A “clone” loads channels into an otherwise fixed zone. You need a laptop with authenticated BK Radio software to do this.
Q2: How can I tell if my radios have the current cloned zones?
A2: The cloned zones have a label. For example at Palisades on 17JAN2025 the zones are labelled “PALIS-E2” & “PALIS-W2”. Each new clone will have unique zone labels (such as PALIS-E3/4/5 etc). Ask at the Radio Clone desk for the current zone labels if you are unsure.
item.dc:creator: George Shoemaker

item.title: Radios BKR 5000
item.description:
SCU Radio Guide 2025
On 06FEB2025, the crew received 6 upgraded BKR 5000 radios. There is a single spare (unlabeled) radio that is shared between both crews.

BKR 5000 clamshell battery packs carry 12 AA batteries (but can operate with just 8).

item.title: Palisades Log
item.description:
Follow the footnotes to see the location of each point.

Palisades Incident Command Post [1]
Station 70 (LA County FD)[2]
Station 69 (LA County FD)[3]
Station 69 (LAFD)[4]




Diverted from Sanborn Project and returned to station for final gear check. Buggy change. Wheels rolling 1400. Plan is to rendezvous with Nevada City Crew in Tracy. We do not, but we link up with more CalFire leadership.
As of this date are the 3 main fires and their acreage:

Hurst : 0.7k acres
Eaton : 10.6k acres
Palisades : 11.8k acres
TODO: Watch Duty screen shot
2330 drove west bound on Sunset blvd, past Station 69[4-1] which was burned over. Majority of structures burned down in this area. I believe the station is still standing, couldn't really see in the dark.
Turned south to the ocean on Temescal Canyon Rd, then west on Highway 1. Burnt down homes and businesses, smokes.
Palisades acreage has exceeded 17k acres. Confluence of factors (fuel load, drought, low humidity, primarily strong winds exceeding 50 mph).


Channels to be scanned:
CMD: LAC V-1
TAC: CDF T40 (for Zulu)
TAC: CDF T39 (for Yankee)
A/G: CDFA/G 15
Briefing at trail head (TODO: GPS). TAC channels for Division Zulu & Yankee.
There is less wind than previous days which makes offensive strategies possible.
Structure defense and reinforcing the creek in Topanga Canyon below Alma Rd. Fire has crept down to the creek and is up on the ridge, keeps flaring up then backing up slope.
Reassigned to cut line through vegetation along the backs of houses (WUI). Area is too steep for dozer. We are within 100 yards of flames down slope. TODO: 09JAN2025 gps. Compare with fire perimeter: did fire reach line? Did it jump line?
Return to trail head (briefing location). Sharpen tools and rehab water. Bed down at 21:30

0300 wake up to widen line behind houses, wind pick up. Goal is to create a sufficient fire break to save the houses without question.
0730 leave for ICP, chow, rehab.
Sleeper trailers at Zuma Beach.

0530 wake up, 0615 chow
Staging, 1030 assigned to further improve line from last shift. Fire has not reached this line yet. Reassigned to cut line around the black on top of hill (TODO: gps) still hot area. Work until we are out of fuel Rehab at buggy, 1600
1700 structure defense in WUI neighborhood in Topanga (TODO gps). Two civilians are filming us remove vegetation around houses, not sure of their intention. Nearly everyone is gone, evac zone. Done at 2130. Rehab, bed down

0600 wake up, wheels rolling at 0700 to return to Zuma Beach ICP[1-1]
Palisades acreage 23.7k
Hotel near Buena Park

Wheels rolling 0530
At chow there are Mexican National Guard soldiers wearing "Ayuda Humanitaria" arm bands.
TODO: GPS Staging 13JAN2025. Some houses burned down in this neighborhood. Assigned at 1030. Drove past the where the dozer pushed cars off the road at Sunset Blvd & Palisades Dr.[5]

Walked up a ridge and turned around, TODO GPS
1300 cut & reinforce existing line. Black is pretty cold. Desert, shrubby vegetation and grass. Mop up and grid and on the hike out. 1930 returned to buggy, rehab, bed down in field.
Here is an Incident Action Plan map of the fire for morning of 13JAN2025

0545 wheels rolling return to yeterday's staging, arrive at ICP[1-2] 0730 chow
1130 wheels rolling to hotel in downtown LA. Urban S&R is picking through burnt down homes near LAFD Station 70[2-1]. I imagine the fire was throwing embers south and it was luck of the draw whose roof succumbed to fire.
Tons of military vehicles staged at Will Rogers Beach[6] parking lot off Highway 1
Palisades Fire has remained at 23.7k acres since 12JAN2025, this thing pretty much done. Containment is up to 18%. There is still a red flag warning in effect with some risk that winds pick up and a new fire makes a run, but this seems more unlikely by the day.


Final acreage for Palisades Fire: 23,448
The crew would go on to work

Pala Fire: 17 acres
Clay Fire: 39 acres
Border 2 Fire: 6,635 acres


Palisades Incident Command Post @ Zuma Beach, Highway 1 & Morning View Dr↩︎↩︎↩︎
Station 70 (LA County FD), 3970 Carbon Canyon Rd, Malibu, CA 90265↩︎↩︎
Station 69 (LA County FD), 401 S Topanga Canyon Blvd, Topanga, CA 90290↩︎
Station 69 (LAFD), 15045 Sunset Blvd, Pacific Palisades, CA 90272↩︎↩︎
Sunset Blvd & Palisades Dr↩︎
Will Rogers Beach, 16321 Pacific Coast Highway↩︎
